etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘reject’, specifically ‘object to a judge as prejudiced’): from Latin recusare ‘to refuse’, from re- (expressing opposition) + causa ‘a cause’. The current sense dates from the early 19th century

definitions: challenge (a judge, prosecutor, or juror) as unqualified to perform legal duties because of a potential conflict of interest or lack of impartiality

examples.text: a motion to recuse the prosecutor

shortDefinitions: challenge judge as unqualified to perform legal duties

definitions: (of a judge) excuse oneself from a case because of a potential conflict of interest or lack of impartiality

examples.text: the Justice Department demanded that he recuse himself from the case
